RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Desde Janeiro/2017, pѓs-doutoranda e docente na Universidade de Helsinki. Doutorado (2017) pela European University Institute (EUI) com financiamento integral da European Research Council. LL.M. (2013) em Comparative, European and International Laws tambщm pela EUI com amparo da bolsa-mщrito Hans Kelsen aos cinco primeiros colocados no processo seletivo. Mestrado Acadъmico em Direito e Desenvolvimento (2011) pela Escola de Direito da FGV-Sуo Paulo com amparo da Bolsa Mario Henrique Simonsen. Bacharel em Direito pela Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Norte (2009). A sua tese de doutorado foi elaborada como parte de um amplo projeto de pesquisa entitulado European Regulatory Private Law Project (2013-2017), o qual serс publicada na integra pela Hart Publishing. Atualmente, щ a investigadora principal do projeto External Dimension of European Private Law (2017-2020) financiado pela Academy of Finland/FiDiPro. Anteriormente, participou como pesquisadora associada em projetos financiados pelo Banco Interamericano de Desenvolvimento (BID) e The Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation (TEKES). Fez parte do corpo editorial dos mais respeitсveis jornais acadъmicos internacionais, entre eles: European Journal of International Law, International Journal of Constitutional Law, e European Journal of Legal Studies.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Lucila de Almeida is a postdoctoral research fellow. She joined the University of Helsinki to carry out investigations on the External Dimension of European Private Law (EDEPL) Project funded by FiDiPro/Academy of Finland. She holds PhD (2017) and LL.M. (2013) from European University Institute, Academic Master in Law and Development from FGV Direito Sуo Paulo (2011), and BA from the Brazilian Federal University UFRN (2009). Lucila's PhD thesis was developed wihtin the framewok of the European Regulatory Private Law (ERPL) Project hosted by EUI and fully funded by ERC, in which she held the position of Associate Researcher (2013-2017). Before joining the externally funded ERPL/ERC Project, she also assisted research projects funded by IDB (2011) and TEKES (2012) on Transnational Private Law. Lucila has been member of the editorial board of top legal journals: Assistant Editor at EJIL and I.CON (2014-2016), and Management (2013-2014) and Senior Editor (2012-) at EJLS. Her fields of research is Private Law Theory, European Private Law (Internal and External Dimensions), and Transnational Private Law with an interest in network indutries particularly Energy Market. At University of Helsinki, Lucila founded and teaches the course on External Dimension of European Private Law, as well as co-teaches Foundations of EU Law (EU Substantive Law).

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: International Product Fragmentation and the Insertion of LAC in Global Production Networks (IDB Research Fund)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The aim of the empirical research is to understand how the supply chains have evolved over time, which factors have driven this evolution and in particular, how a specific set of contractual practices along these chains is linked to access international markets. The two selected case studies - agriculture and aeronautics - permit comparison between the different modes os accessing international markets and GVCs; they illustrate the roles of transnational corporations and those of public institutions both at domestic and international levels to promote access and to determine its modes and the potential spillover effects onto local production systems. More specifically, the research tries to identify the alternative channels of access to GVCs and international markets, and the institutional, legal and economic obstacles, which prevent to access or make it very costly. It looks at the role of intermediaries who control access to internationl markets, examining when they operate as gateways and when as bottlenecks. It examines both private and public actors, trying to disentangle when they facilitate and when they hinder access. It focus on the most relevant factors that may attract foreign direct investment in human and physical capital to Brazil.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: International Product Fragmentation and the Insertion of LAC in Global Production Networks (IDB)

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Transnational private regulation (TPR) and System Level Innovations in Global Food Value Chains (TEKES Grant Agreement)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The scope of this research is to investigate how transnational private regulation and contractual networks enable system level innovations in socio-technical regime of food in two sectors: coffee and sugarcane. For this purpose, the research is divided in two parts. The first aim of this research is to find out how the private and public regulation and contractual networks can trigger and promote system level innovations in global value chains. As an outcome we can make some policy recommendations. The case studies will be conducted primarily in Finland, Italy and Brazil from different value chains. They will focus on the understanding system-level enablers and constraints for innovations and on the regulatory role of contracts and TPRs for food safety and sustainability along the supply chain. The Second aim is to find out how regulation (especially private regulation), contractual networks and innovations correlate. Our hypothesis is that if enacted through appropriate instruments, private regulation can trigger technological innovation by inducing parties to produce and share complementary knowledge, to make specific investments, or the like. Institutions allocating technological knowledge, IPRs, and other resources play an important role in tackling societal challenges e.g. food safety. Contractual networks should also be seen as tools to govern the allocation of knowledge-related rights.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: O principal objetivo da pesquisa щ investigar como Regulaчуo Privada Transnacional (RPT) e redes contratuais criam sistemas de inovaчѕes no regime tщcnico-social de produчуo de alimentos. O primeiro objetivѓ щ identificar como a regulaчуo pњblica e privada e as redes contratuais podem promover sistema de inovaчѕes em cadeias produtivas globais. Para isso, a pesquisa estс baseada em estudos de casos por diferentes cadeias produtivas que englobam atores localizados na Finlтndia, na Itсlia e no Brasil. O foco щ compreender as faclidades e dificuldades do sistema de inovaчѕes e o papel regulatѓrio dos contratos e da RPT para a seguranчa e sustentabilidade na produчуo de alimentos ao longo da cadeia produtiva. O segundo objetivo щ entender como regulaчуo (especificamente regulaчуo privada), redes contratuais e inovaчуo estуo correlacionadas. A hipѓtese щ que, atravщs do uso de instrumentos apropriados, a regulaчуo privada pode fomentar inovaчуo tecnolѓgica atravщs do incentivo рs partes produzirem e transferirem conhecimento ou fazer investimentos especэficos. A alocaчуo de conhecimento tecnolѓgico, IPRs e outros recursos por instituiчѕes tem um papel importante para remover barreiras. Redes contratuais sуo tambщm ferramentas importantes para administrar a alocaчуo de conhecimento relacionada р propriedade intelectual.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Transnational private regulation (TPR) and System Level Innovations in Global Food Value Chains

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation

EUI Working Group on European Private Law

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: European Regulatory Private Law (European Research Council Grant Agreement n. 269722)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
The ERPL challenges the basis of our understanding of private law. Is the European Union ? with the support of the majority of the Member States ? ?destroying? ?our? national private law systems? What kind of private law is the European Union creating? Recalling de-juridification, de-politicisation and de-judicialisation (Joerges), can it continue to be regarded as law? (Walker) Is it a private legal order of big companies and informed customers/consumers who behave like small businessmen? Where do the truly weak groups stand and what role should be granted to small and medium sized companies?
The project proposes the use of Schumpeter?s formula of creative destruction as the starting point of analysis. Taken literally this formula would mean that private law, and its conception over centuries as an order inherently linked to the idea of a nation state, is drawing to an end. The European legislator would then be the ?terminator?, who is undermining the ideological basis of the different national private legal orders, the overall assumption that Privatautonomie, freedom of contract and autonomie de la volontщ are the sole and decisive denominators. The standard justification for the opposite position is that ERPL does not develop in a legal vacuum. It is said to be based on and dependent of the national private law systems.
Much depends on the understanding, the role and the function of the state in a market economy. The European Union is not a fully-fledged state, but it is a strong regulator of private law relationships. In this sense, the European Union has much in common with the idea of the ?market state?. If we assume that the European regulator is disconnecting national private legal orders from their ideological basis, the question remains then as to what is ?constructive? in the destruction process? I begin from the premise that the EU is yielding a new concept of private law, one which is distinct from national preconceptions and one genuinely anchored in the European legal order.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: European Regulatory Private Law: the Transformation of European Private Law from Autonomy to Functionalism in Competition and Regulation

VINCULOS.OUTRAS-INFORMACOES: PhD Researcher in the Project "European Regulatory Private Law: the Transformation of European Private Law from Autonomy to Functionalism in Competition and Regulation".

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: External Dimension of European Private Law (Academy of Finland Grant Agreement n. 283002)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The External Dimension of European Private Law (EDEPL) is funded by the Academy of Finland. Distinguished as research of scientific excellence, the project receives funding under the Finland Distinguished Professor (FiDiPro) funding programme. The FiDiPro/EDEPL project focuses on searching for the potential influence and impact of the European Union on international organizations and institutions in private law making, on powerful states such as the United States, Brazil, China, Japan and Russia as well as on economic regions such as Mercosur, the ASEAN Countries and Africa. The perspective has been changed from inward to outward, to private law beyond the European Union and through the European Union. The project is built around the vertical (regulatory private law in the various sector related markets) and the horizontal (the interaction between European Union Civil/Contract Code building and similar attempts in the various economic regions around the world) dimensions of private law beyond the European Union, in order to develop a deeper understanding of the transformation processes that private law rules are currently undergoing. European private law (regulatory and traditional contract law) in its internal and external dimension is suggested to serve as a blueprint and model for the development of a normative design of bifurcated private law. Research on the external dimension of European Private Law is still in its infancy. However, it is possible to group the debate around four major observations which seem to hold the external European private law together and which indicate a move: (1) (from) legal rules and (to) legal practice; (2) (from) formal law making and (to) European governance; (3) (from) substantive law and (to) procedural law; (4) (from) private law and (to) trade law. It will have to be shown that the ?from? to? by and large corresponds to the distinction between traditional private law and regulatory private law.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: External Dimension of European Private Law

Florence School of Regulation and European Regulatory Private Law Project: Open Discussion on a common research agenda

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS:
The ERPL-ERC Project is a pioneering research hosted at EUI Law Department under the scientific guidance of Prof. Hans - W. Micklitz. The focus of this socio-legal project lies in the search for a normative model which could shape a self-sufficient European private legal order in its interaction with the national private law system. The fields of analysis are united by predominant Internal Market perspective inclined to the European Regulatory Private Law, which include regulated markets such as energy, telecommunication and financial sector.
The Florence School of Regulation (FSR) is a research center that works as a forum where decision-makers, whether regulators, companies, the European Commission or national authorities meet with academics and experts to debate the most contested topics in regulated markets as Energy, Communications & Media as well as Transport (need to revise)
The objective of this Open Discussion is to bring together Professors and PhD Researches at the Law Department involved in ERPL-ERC Project to present their research and find out a common agenda for organizing joint events with the FSR. The whole EUI Community is very welcome to join this open discussion.
